step.context: \text{Which of the following shows correct}\\ \text{values for f(x) as defined above?}
\text{f(x) will be differentiable at x = 1} \\ \text{and x = 2 }\textbf{if}\ldots
step.reason: \text{For a function f(x) to be differentiable}\\ \text{at x = a, its rate of change on either side of x = a}\\ \text{should be the same. The correct option is simply}\\ \text{the mathematical expression of that fact.}

step.context: \text{Are the analysis and conclusion below correct?}
step.tex: \text{At x = 1} \\ \begin{align} \lim_{x\to 1^-}\dfrac{\left[1\right] - \left[1-h\right]}{h} &= \dfrac{1-0}{h} = \dfrac{1}{h} \\ \text{And, }\lim_{x\to 1^+}\dfrac{\left[1+h\right]-\left[1\right]}{h} &= \dfrac{1-1}{h}= 0 \end{align} \\ \text{Similarly, at x = 2} \\ \begin{align} \lim_{x\to 2^-}\dfrac{\left[2\right] - \left[2-h\right]}{h} &= \dfrac{2-1}{h} = \dfrac{1}{h} \\ \text{And, }\lim_{x\to 2^+}\dfrac{\left[2+h\right]-\left[2\right]}{h} &= \dfrac{2-2}{h}= 0 \end{align} \\ \text{As at both x = 1 and x = 2, the limits are} \\ \text{not equal, f(x) is not differentiable at }\\ \text{both of those points.}
step.reason: \text{Use the condition for differentiability from}\\ \text{Step 2 at x = 1 and x = 2. You will see that}\\ \text{at both x = 1 and x = 2, the limits don't} \\ \text{match}\implies \text{non-differentiability.}
